Problem:
Consider the equation of a vibrating string given by the partial differential equation \\( u_{tt} = c^2 u_{xx} \\), where \\( c \\) is the speed of the wave in the string and \\( u(x,t) \\) represents the displacement at position \\( x \\) and time \\( t \\). An external forcing term \\( F(x,t) \\) is added to the system, resulting in a modified equation \\( u_{tt} = c^2 u_{xx} + F(x,t) \\).

If a specific force pattern \\( F(x,t) = g(t) \\) is applied at some time interval and then switched off, will the string's displacement \\( u(x,T) \\) solely depend on the original wave equation \\( u_{tt} = c^2 u_{xx} \\) for times larger than when \\( g(t) \\) was last applied?
Explanation: The introduction and subsequent removal of the force \\( g(t) \\) impacts the initial conditions post-intervention. Therefore, the resultant trajectory of the string is influenced by the interplay of the natural dynamics and the temporary forcing, affecting the displacement at later times.
